Crispy, creamy, crunchy — those are big — but I also like “smashed,” as in smashed burgers, smashed cucumbers, smashed pickle salad. “Double” is another; If you love garlic, lemon or chocolate, you can close your eyes and imagine the potency of double garlic mashed potatoes, double lemon chicken or double chocolate chip cookies.Then there is the Yiddish word “schmaltzy,” which has two meanings: slicked with rendered chicken fat (technically, any poultry fat); and overly sentimental, with high notes and big strings. It’s an over-the-top word with a showbiz quality to it. A schmaltzy chicken is a chicken doing a tap routine with a feather boa; it’s going to give you big flavor whether you like it or not. Personally, I like it.

Spread out over half a mile on a bluff 70 feet above the Concho River, Paint Rock derives its name from the pictographs on the layers of limestone shelves. Using massive flat-faced boulders as canvases, nomadic tribes painted and etched more than 1,500 individual images — tomahawks, winged serpents, a Spanish mission, a turtle drawn so that, on the winter solstice, a dagger of light strikes its back at solar noon, the moment when the sun sits highest in the sky.

content: They heard from top New Jersey government officials. They reviewed scores of personal text messages and emails. They even felt the weight of gold bullion in their hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Corruption Verdict Could Decide How Menendez’s Senate Career Ends
description: This is likely to be the last year of Robert Menendez’s time in the Senate, no matter the outcome of his trial. But he could resign or be expelled if he’s found guilty.
content: Robert Menendez’s Senate career is very likely to end this year regardless of the outcome of his corruption trial. But the verdict may determine exactly how.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Takeaways From Day One of the Republican Convention
description: Donald Trump and his newly minted running mate, J.D. Vance, were officially nominated, but Mr. Trump’s triumphal prime-time emergence in the arena that might prove the indelible moment of the whole event.
content: An emotional first day of the Republican National Convention ended Monday night with an official ticket for 2024, Donald J. Trump and J.D. Vance, but it was Mr. Trump’s triumphal prime-time emergence in the arena, just two days after a failed assassination attempt, that might prove the indelible moment of the whole event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Jonathan Weisman
title: In Leaked Phone Call, Trump Tries to Coax Kennedy Into His Camp
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. apologized for a leaked video of the phone call, in which Donald Trump questions the safety of childhood vaccines and says the injury to his ear “felt like the world’s largest mosquito.”
content: A leaked video of a phone call between former President Donald J. Trump and the independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on the day after the attempted assassination of Mr. Trump offered a behind-the-scenes look into the former president’s efforts to coax Mr. Kennedy out of the race and into his camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Move Over, La Guardia and Newark: 18 Artists to Star at New J.F.K. Terminal
description: Terminal 6 at Kennedy International Airport will feature work by Charles Gaines, Barbara Kruger and more. Developers of new terminals must invest in public art.
content: John F. Kennedy International Airport’s new Terminal 6, scheduled to open in 2026, will host installations by 18 contemporary artists hailing from seven countries, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: After a National Anthem Flub, Singer Says She’s Going to Rehab
description: Ingrid Andress, a country star, blamed drinking for her performance of “The Star-Spangled Banner” during Major League Baseball’s All-Star Game festivities.
content: The country music star Ingrid Andress became one of many high-profile singers who have had trouble pulling off “The Star-Spangled Banner” when she sang it during Major League Baseball’s All-Star Game festivities before a capacity crowd at Globe Life Field in Arlington, Texas, on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Donald Trump’s running mate.
content: On the first day of the Republican National Convention, Donald Trump announced his running mate: J.D. Vance, a 39-year-old senator and ex-Marine who, over the last few years, has transformed from a sharp critic of the former president into one of his most loyal allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Former White House Doctor Describes Tending to Trump’s Wounded Ear
description: Ronny Jackson, former President Donald J. Trump’s White House doctor and now a congressman from Texas, replaced the dressing on Mr. Trump’s ear on a flight to Milwaukee on Sunday.
content: Representative Ronny Jackson, Republican of Texas, was on Donald J. Trump’s plane on Sunday afternoon, the day after the former president survived an assassination attempt, when he quickly reverted to his role of doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Dysfunction Sidelines Ukraine’s Parliament as Governing Force
description: With the president’s party split, the government relies on formerly pro-Russian lawmakers to help it pass legislation and, the opposition says, minimize scrutiny.
content: Ukraine’s Parliament is in a state of disarray.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A ‘Breathtaking’ Dismissal of the Trump Documents Case
description: Readers strongly disagree with Judge Aileen Cannon’s decision.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Jack Black Ends Tenacious D Tour After Bandmate Jokes About Trump Shooting
description: At a concert in Australia, Kyle Gass made a comment suggesting that he wished the shooter had not missed former President Trump during an assassination attempt.
content: Tenacious D, the American comedy-rock duo that includes the movie star Jack Black, announced on Tuesday that the remainder of its tour would be canceled and that all future plans were on pause after the band’s other member, Kyle Gass, made an offhand comment onstage about the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Detected Potential Iranian Plot to Kill Trump Separate From Saturday’s Shooting
description: American intelligence agencies were tracking an Iranian threat even before the attack on former President Donald J. Trump. But officials said the two were unrelated.
content: U.S. intelligence agencies were tracking a potential Iranian assassination plot against former President Donald J. Trump in the weeks before a gunman opened fire last weekend, several officials said on Tuesday, but they added that they did not consider the threat related to the shooting that wounded Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: Widow of Slain Rally Attendee Says She Received Call From Trump
description: Corey Comperatore, 50, was killed while attending a rally for Donald J. Trump for the first time.
content: The widow of the slain victim in Saturday’s shooting in Pennsylvania spoke with former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday, she said in a social media post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: The End of a Strategic Deployment
description: As the aircraft carrier Eisenhower returned home, the U.S. national security adviser assessed the Biden administration’s efforts to contain the conflict in the Middle East.
content: As the aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower sailed toward Norfolk Harbor, a small cargo plane landed on the flight deck amid swirling wind and rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Continetti
title: Why Trump Picked J.D. Vance
description: The former president was probably thinking of 2028 and beyond — and where he wants the G.O.P. to go.
content: Donald Trump’s contempt for the Washington establishment is well known. He challenges, confronts and subverts its institutions, its media, its consultants, its euphemisms and its unwritten codes of conduct. Choosing Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio to be his running mate is the latest example of the former president’s willingness to flout political convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Dr. Ruth’s Tips for a Happy Life
description: Ruth Westheimer loved to give advice — and often strayed from her area of expertise as she tried, in her words, “to make the world a better place.”
content: Ruth Westheimer spent a lot of time talking about sex. She did so with her own brand of frankness and good cheer on her pioneering radio show, “Sexually Speaking,” and on her daytime TV program, “The Dr. Ruth Show,” as well as in her column for Playgirl magazine, in her many books and in countless interviews and public appearances across more than four decades. It’s possible that Dr. Ruth, who died last week at 96, talked publicly about sex more than anyone else. Ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Wales’s First Minister Steps Down After Rising Pressure From Colleagues
description: Vaughan Gething became the first minister of Wales in March. But a growing controversy over campaign financing precipitated his decision to resign.
content: Vaughan Gething, the first minister of Wales, announced his resignation on Tuesday after less than four months, amid a controversy over campaign donations that prompted a vote of no confidence in his leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler
title: Videos Show Secret Service Snipers Were Focused Toward Gunman at Trump Rally
description: Three videos posted to social media show that sniper teams were facing in the direction of the shooter before he fired at former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Three videos posted on social media show that Secret Service snipers were orienting themselves toward the gunman at the Trump rally just under two minutes before shots were fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Grass Lawns: Lavish and Lamentable
description: We are honoring the Top 9 winners of our Student Open Letter Contest by publishing their entries. This one is by Lucy Robb, age 17.
content: Dear American Lawn Owner,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: How Would Ohio Replace Vance in the Senate if Trump Wins in November?
description: State law instructs the governor to appoint a replacement until a special election can be held. Several Republican names are already circulating as potential prospects.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has selected Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio as his vice-presidential running mate. Should they win in November, Mr. Vance would vacate the Senate seat he won just two years ago with four years still left in his term, leaving it open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: What to Expect From Wednesday’s Emmy Nominations
description: The top nominees are announced at 11:30 a.m. ET. “Shogun” and “The Bear” are poised to have a big day.
content: Just six months after a strike-delayed ceremony, the Emmys are back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Anupreeta Das
title: Bangladesh Deploys Border Force to Try to Quell Student Protests
description: Across the country, students have taken to the streets over job quotas that they say limit their opportunities.
content: Bangladesh deployed a paramilitary force on Tuesday after at least five people were killed during violent demonstrations by thousands of university students, raising the specter of instability in a country familiar with protests.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For the G.O.P., Free-Market Economics Is History
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 16, 2024.
content: “The party is becoming whatever President Trump wants it to be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Naomi Pomeroy, 49, Chef Who Made Portland a Dining Destination, Dies
description: Her refined palate and pursuit of excellence made her the city’s culinary matriarch, attracting diners and talent alike to Oregon. She died in a tubing accident.
content: Naomi Pomeroy, a self-taught chef with an irreverent streak whose high standards and generosity of spirit made her the culinary matriarch of Portland, Ore., as it emerged as the locus of a radical new style of fine dining in the mid-2000s, died on Saturday near Corvallis, Ore. She was 49.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Italian Pop Discoveries From My Vacation
description: Hear songs from Angelina Mango, Patty Pravo and an unexpected hit by Conan Gray.
content: I’m back! Thank you to my editor, Caryn Ganz, for filling in for me for the past two weeks while I was on vacation visiting a friend in Italy. I was mostly in and around Florence, but I also made some excursions to Siena, Bologna and Rome. As relaxing as that sounds, know that my ears weren’t completely on vacation. As always, I was constantly discovering new music, and I’m going to share some of those finds with you in today’s playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: A Somber Late Night After the Attack on Trump
description: Stephen Colbert and Seth Meyers offered sober reflections about democracy. So did Anthony Anderson, though he found some humor in the reaction to the shooting.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Gareth Southgate’s England Tenure Ends With a Jump, Not a Push
description: Southgate’s eight years in charge made him the most successful England manager in decades. In stepping down two days after losing the Euro 2024 final, he got the last word.
content: Outside Gareth Southgate’s office at St. George’s Park, the remote training facility that serves as the home of English soccer, a series of portraits had been mounted on the wall. They depicted the 14 men who had preceded him in what was once described as the second-most important job in the country: manager of the England men’s soccer team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Two Hikers Die in Canyonlands National Park in 100-Degree Temperatures
description: A father and daughter were found dead in the park after they texted 911 that they ran out of water and were lost while hiking in triple-digit temperatures.
content: A man and his daughter died in Canyonlands National Park in Utah on Friday after they ran out of water and texted 911 for help while hiking along a challenging trail in temperatures of well over 100 degrees, according to the park officials and the San Juan County Sheriff’s Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman
title: D.N.C. Aims to Push Biden Toward Nomination Next Week, Despite Doubts
description: Leaders of the Democratic National Committee are aiming for a process that would formalize the nomination by the end of July, even as Democrats remain fiercely split over his candidacy.
content: Leaders of the Democratic National Committee are moving swiftly to confirm President Biden as his party’s presidential nominee by the end of July, according to four people briefed on the matter who insisted on anonymity to discuss the sensitive deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Biden Finally Got Border Numbers Down. Will He See the Political Benefits?
description: June had the lowest monthly total for illegal crossings since January 2021. But the downturn comes amid intense focus on President Biden’s candidacy and the attempted assassination of Donald Trump.
content: The number of migrants crossing the southern border has dropped sharply since the Biden administration imposed severe restrictions on asylum last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Crisis Hotline Has Answered 10 Million Calls, Texts and Chats
description: Mental health experts have said that the 988 hotline for mental health emergencies is still a work in progress, in need of more funding, coordination and awareness.
content: More than 10 million calls, texts and chat messages have been answered by counselors working for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline’s three-digit hotline in the two years since it debuted, federal officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender, Andrew Trunsky and Neil Vigdor
title: After Saturday, Trump’s Devotees See ‘God’s Protection’
description: Some of Donald J. Trump’s followers had long viewed him as handpicked by God. The attempted assassination has only increased such quasi-religious devotion and rhetoric.
content: For Donald J. Trump’s most devoted supporters, the bullet that nicked his ear and came within inches of ending his life was only further proof that a higher power is looking out for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: Luther S. Allison, a Jazz Pianist With Big Hands and Bigger Traditions
description: The musician, 28, has won a Grammy for his work with Samara Joy and earned the respect of the elders who mentored him. His debut album is due Friday.
content: On a beautiful day in Harlem a few months before the release of his debut album, Luther S. Allison stood chatting a few yards away from Duke Ellington’s white baby grand. Allison, a wiry 6’4” with huge hands and a contagious enthusiasm, was surrounded by history at the National Jazz Museum — Eddie Lockjaw Davis’s tenor saxophone, the famous Great Day in Harlem photo of 57 musicians taken on a stoop on 126th Street. It was a fitting scene for the pianist, a 28-year-old up-and-comer who’s drawn comparisons to Mulgrew Miller and learned to use the past as fuel for his own future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Christie
title: Chris Christie: Will Trump Meet the Moment?
description: The Republican nominee has the opportunity to rein in some of the worst rhetorical impulses of his party and point it in a new direction.
content: There is no place for political violence in this country. That is the recurring sentiment expressed by elected officials and political leaders since the attempted assassination of Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Night 1
description: Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the opening night for Republicans in Milwaukee.
content: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 1 of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Donald Trump and his party; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches from Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Senator Tim Scott and Sean O’Brien, the president of the Teamsters, who was given a prime slot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How You Helped Us Cover More Corners of California
description: During my time on the newsletter, I had a goal to report from all of the state’s 58 counties. Readers came through with plenty of ideas.
content: Editor’s note: Starting next week, California Today will have a new look. It will still arrive in your inbox every weekday morning and feature a curated collection of New York Times articles about the state, but it will no longer include a staff-written introduction each day. For more details, please read Monday’s newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How to Upgrade Your Kitchen Without Actually Renovating
description: You don’t have to spend a lot to remake your kitchen. Instead, try these six D.I.Y. hacks.
content: Kitchen renovations can be time-consuming and costly. But what if you don’t have a lot of time or money?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman
title: The Judge in Menendez’s Trial Has Overseen Several High-Profile Cases
description: Judge Sidney H. Stein, who has almost 30 years of experience on the bench, has instilled a keen sense of order throughout the proceedings.
content: Two months ago, as the federal corruption trial of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey loomed, Mr. Menendez’s lawyers made another of many requests to the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debby Applegate
title: When Gangland Was Jewish
description: Two exuberant new books chronicle the heyday of New York City’s criminal underworld on the Lower East Side.
content: One hundred years ago, New York City was in the midst of what newspapers decried as “a Jewish crime wave.” The causes were complex, but most observers at the time laid the blame on Prohibition, which created a lucrative black market for alcohol overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Tracey Tully, Nicholas Fandos and Maria Cramer
title: Menendez Convicted of Corruption in Broad International Conspiracy
description: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, was found guilty of bribery, conspiracy, extortion, obstruction of justice and acting as a foreign agent.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, a powerful Democrat who once led the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was convicted on Tuesday of participating in a vast international bribery scheme, in which prosecutors said he had accepted gold, cash and other payoffs worth hundreds of thousands of dollars in exchange for political favors abroad and at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: After Backlash, Marvel Gives an Israeli Superhero a New Backstory
description: The studio said Sabra, a Mossad agent in comic books, will be “a high-ranking U.S. government official” in its next Captain America movie.
content: When Marvel Studios announced two years ago that it had cast the Israeli actress Shira Haas to play Sabra, a superhero Mossad agent, in its next “Captain America” film, the news was cheered by Israelis and denounced by Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Christine Hauser
title: String of Storms Batters Chicago and Leaves Damage Across Midwest
description: The system brought dangerous winds, rain and possible tornadoes to Iowa, Illinois and Indiana, killing at least one person in Indiana.
content: At least one person died on Monday as a line of thunderstorms brought powerful wind gusts and possible tornadoes to parts of Iowa, Illinois and Indiana, causing power outages and widespread damage, officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Rare Attack in Oman on Shiite Worshipers Leaves 6 People Dead
description: Assailants attacked worshipers in Oman observing the Shiite day of mourning Ashura, in an unusual eruption of violence in a normally peaceful Gulf nation that prides itself on religious tolerance.
content: Multiple assailants, at least one of them armed, staged a rare attack in the Gulf nation of Oman that targeted worshipers near a mosque, many of them from Pakistan, leaving six people dead on a Shiite Muslim day of mourning, the Omani and Pakistani authorities said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ehrenreich
title: A Brutal Gang, a Dead Baby and a Struggling Immigrant L.A.
description: Jesse Katz’s true-crime narrative, “The Rent Collectors,” delivers a nuanced portrait of a community racked by poverty and violence and deprived of opportunities to get ahead.
content: On the evening of Sept. 15, 2007, 18-year-old Giovanni Macedo marched down a crowded sidewalk in the MacArthur Park neighborhood of Los Angeles, pointed a .22-caliber pistol at the head of a street vendor named Francisco Clemente and pulled the trigger five times. Clemente was severely injured, but he survived. One of the bullets that Macedo fired, though, killed an infant sleeping in a stroller a few feet away. His name was Luis Angel Garcia. He was 23 days old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael C. Bender, Carlos Prieto, Clare Toeniskoetter, Jessica Cheung, Mooj Zadie, Eric Krupke, Rikki Novetsky, Brendan Klinkenberg, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Corey Schreppel and Alyssa Moxley
title: Trump Picks His Running Mate, and Political Heir
description: Former President Donald J. Trump chose the 39-year-old Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio as his vice-presidential nominee.
content: On the first day of the Republican National Convention, Donald J. Trump chose his running mate: Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan’s Blunt-Talking Leader Faces China’s Backlash
description: China is putting more military and political pressure on Taiwan and its new president, whose rhetoric has been sharper than his predecessor’s.
content: The long-smoldering tensions between China and Taiwan have been entering a more precarious phase. In recent months, Beijing has threatened to severely punish Taiwanese citizens who challenge China’s claim to the island. More Chinese jets have buzzed the skies near it. Chinese Coast Guard ships have sailed near Taiwan’s outer islands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amil Niazi
title: And Now, the Millennial Midlife-Crisis Novel
description: In Halle Butler’s new book, “Banal Nightmare,” a 30-something woman returns to her hometown to get out of a rut and reassess her life after a bad breakup.
content: There are some novels so searingly precise in their ability to capture a certain moment or experience that you have to stop every few pages to send another perfect quote to your group chat. Halle Butler’s latest, “Banal Nightmare,” is one such book, with painfully accurate renderings of everything from the lackluster dating pool of heterosexual men (“For the love of god, no more losers, no more strivers, no more men with something to prove about themselves”) to the imbalance of domestic duties between the sexes (“She did all of the laundry, cooked all of the meals, took out the trash, cleaned, shopped, paid the bills, all of it, he did none of it, she did all of it, holy god for 10 years all of it”) to the pampering of millennials (“the coddling infantilization of her generation, who, though well into their 30s, seemed to need constant affirmation and authoritative direction to make it through the week”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Evan Wright, Award-Winning Reporter and Author of ‘Generation Kill,’ Dies at 59
description: His best seller about Marines in Iraq, members of a “disposable generation,” was made into an HBO mini-series. He focused on subjects outside mainstream media coverage.
content: Evan Wright, an award-winning journalist whose reporting from the Iraq War formed the best-selling book “Generation Kill” and whose work illuminated the lives of those on the fringes of society, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: 10 Years After Eric Garner’s Death, an Opera Honors His Legacy
description: “The Ritual of Breath Is the Rite to Resist,” part of Lincoln Center’s summer festival, aims to shine light on police violence in the United States.
content: In the middle of “The Ritual of Breath Is the Rite to Resist,” an opera about the police killing of Eric Garner, a singer portraying his daughter reflects on his famous final words: “I can’t breathe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran’s New President Promises Changes. Can He Deliver?
description: Masoud Pezeshkian, a widowed doctor, portrays himself as a reformer who can bring social and economic shifts. But others have tried and failed before him, and numerous obstacles are in his path.
content: Iran’s president-elect, Masoud Pezeshkian, walked through a leafy cemetery, glanced at tombstones and sat by the one bearing his wife’s name. Moments later he was riding in a car, weeping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca F. Elliott and Desiree Rios
title: Why Is the Oil Industry Booming?
description: High prices and growing demand have helped U.S. oil producers take in record profits despite global efforts to spur greater use of renewable energy and electric cars.
content: For all of the focus on an energy transition, the American oil industry is booming, extracting more crude than ever from the shale rock that runs beneath the ground in West Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Nick Corasaniti
title: Republican Speakers Wrestle With a ‘Unity’ Theme
description: Some of the most bombastic Republicans made calls to tone down the rhetoric after the attempt on Donald Trump’s life, but animosity toward President Biden persisted.
content: After former President Donald J. Trump called for a unifying message after the assassination attempt against him over the weekend, some Republicans known for their bombastic rhetoric were quick to oblige.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Jess Bidgood
title: With J.D. Vance and a Bandaged Ear, Trump Gets His Party Started
description: A dispatch from Night 1 of the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.
content: Republicans had a big day on Monday. Donald Trump picked J.D. Vance as his running mate. Two days after surviving an assassination attempt, he officially became his party’s presidential nominee. And the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee got underway, with a festive mood among the delegates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Elon Musk Allies Help Start Pro-Trump Super PAC
description: The group, America PAC, is funded by several wealthy tech entrepreneurs in Mr. Musk’s social circle and is said to be likely to draw financial support from the SpaceX and Tesla founder himself.
content: Some of Elon Musk’s closest friends have helped start a new super PAC meant to help former President Donald J. Trump, creating an avenue for Mr. Musk and his $250 billion fortune to potentially play a significant role in the 2024 presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Appraising J.D. Vance as Trump’s Running Mate
description: Readers discuss his credentials, his devotion to the ex-president and how the choice might affect the race.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Climate and the Republican Convention
description: Here’s where the party stands on global warming, energy and the environment.
content: It’s official: Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the presidential election this November, and Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio is his running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: James B. Sikking, Actor Best Known for ‘Hill Street Blues,’ Dies at 90
description: His natural rectitude landed him roles on hundreds of TV dramas and comedies, including the beloved “Car Pool Lane” episode of “Curb Your Enthusiasm.”
content: James B. Sikking, an actor who specialized in comically and threateningly stern men, died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Was Married to a Terrible Man’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: It was an ordinary weekend with my grandmother, us making mango ice cream by hand at her large table in Kolkata. “You know I was married to a terrible man. Your grandfather killed all my dreams and made me, a college-educated woman, have five children against my will and cook all day.” With these words, my 80-year-old grandmother took her husband of 60 years, a man revered for his scholarly presence and success, off the pedestal. Her confession elevated my standard for love. That day I vowed to shine bright and never let a man or marriage dim my light. — Gargi Sen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: The Most Memorable Reviews by Pete Wells
description: The Times’s restaurant critic is stepping down after a dozen years on the job. Here are some of his most engaging reviews and essays.
content: As The New York Times’s restaurant critic for the last dozen years, Pete Wells has reported from the dining-room trenches on a changing industry. When he started the job in late 2011, old-guard restaurants like Le Cirque and the Four Seasons were still humming, with the help of expense-account diners. The #MeToo movement and the pandemic, which reshaped restaurant kitchens, were years away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Here Is Where It’s Going to Be Hottest on Tuesday
description: Dangerous heat is expected from Texas to New Jersey through Wednesday before milder air starts to sweep across the region.
content: In most areas of the United States, the warmest day of the year is typically recorded in July. So it’s no surprise that most weather maps are red hot on Tuesday, with temperatures expected to reach above 100 in a strip from the Southwest to the Mid-Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Julian Barnes and Michael Levenson
title: Israeli Airstrikes Kill Over 20, Gazans Say, and Hit Another U.N. Building
description: The Israeli military said it was targeting militants operating in a U.N. school being used as a shelter in Nuseirat. A second strike caused fatalities in Al-Mawasi, the Gazan Health Ministry said.
content: Two Israeli strikes killed more than 20 people in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, including at a United Nations school turned shelter, according to local health officials, the latest in a string of recent bombardments that have hit U.N. buildings in the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: A Mystery in Bangkok: Six People Found Dead in Hotel Room
